oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Scott McQuaig Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Scott McQuaig (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Scott McQuaig; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie jokes about Scott McQuaig's album title Scott McQuaig, and McQuaig reveals it was originally set to be based off the first track "Honky Tonk Amnesia" -- (00:32) McQuaig tells that he wrote "A Law Against Leavin'" with Louis Anderson; McQuaig reveals he was working as a tool and die maker when the song came to him -- (01:16) Collie asks about McQuaig's musical history, and McQuaig recalls learning Jimmy Rogers' "That's Why I'm Blue" at his grandfather's home -- (02:18) Collie introduces " High Friends In Places (All Over Town)," and McQuaig reveals he did not write it -- (02:52) Collie inquires about McQuaig's musical tastes, and McQuaig lists: Merle Haggard, blues, and Muddy Waters -- (03:40) McQuaig discusses being in a pre-production meeting when he was introduced to "Honky Tonk Amnesia" -- (04:12) Collie and McQuaig joke about how Whitey Shafer may be a good song-writer one day -- (04:30) Collie and McQuaig discuss how his version of "Honky Tonk Amnesia" has a different style than the original recording -- (04:55) McQuaig discusses how music videos narrow the range of interpretations for a song by giving the song a visual representation -- (05:20) Collie and McQuaig reflect on how McQuaig had no idea what he wanted to be when he was younger -- (05:34) McQuaig declares that the Andy Griffith Show is his favorite show, and Collie and McQuaig discuss their ability to re-watch an episode; Collie reflects on how people can only do a routine once but music is unending -- (06:58) Collie remembers how a comedian will only use the same couple jokes over and over again; McQuaig reflects on how there are a couple albums that he can listen to multiple times -- (08:00) "I Will Always Wait For You" is described to be a swing song that is called the 'Hoagy Carmichael' song; McQuaig recalls working with J. Fred Knobloch at Hank Williams' home -- (09:16) Collie and McQuaig discuss how McQuaig was introduced to Tex Whitson -- (10:34) McQuaig discusses how winning the Jimmy Rogers Festival Talent Show changed McQuaig's opinion of himself from just being a song-writer -- (11:59) Collie introduces Scott McQuaig and "Johnny And The Dreamers," and McQuaig reflects on how " Johnny And The Dreamers" is about how people separate to follow their dreams -- (13:05) Collie recalls how Dizzy Dean would continuously tell different journalists different background information -- (13:57) McQuaig reflects on a line in "Johnny And The Dreamers" that says, 'every time he swings that hammer, he bends a guitar string' -- (14:19) "Old Memory" is told by McQuaig to be a song that reminds him of a veteran returning from war -- (15:06) Collie and McQuaig discuss what it takes to create a cord that has an impact -- (15:55) Collie asks if McQuaig carries a pencil on him, and McQuaig says that he has to write down a lyric within twenty minutes of thinking of it -- (16:25) "Plans Of A Leavin' Man" is told by McQuaig to be a song that Paul Overstreet helped him on, and McQuaig tells that session musicians love recording "Plans Of A Leavin' Man" -- (16:55) McQuaig says "Plans Of A Leavin' Man" has 'Paul Overstreet magic' that you do not know why you like it -- (17:23) Collie asks about McQuaig's childhood influences, and McQuaig reveals his father drowned when McQuaig was young; McQuaig tells that his step-father had stepped into the role of father -- (18:30) Colle and McQuaig discuss McQuaig's position in his family tree -- (19:00) "Take The Smile From Your Face" is revealed by McQuaig to be a true story about a fight McQuaig can not remember -- (19:49) McQuaig recalls when he heard Quinton Powers playing a powerful melody, and McQuaig decided to record "The Little Senorita With Green Eyes" -- (21:08) McQuaig says that the only difficulty in traveling is being away from his family, and McQuaig reveals his joy he gets when he plays Bobby Wills' songs -- (22:01) McQuaig reflects on how he wishes to continue to record, and McQuaig remembers how Haggard only wished to make a living -- (22:40) McQuaig shows his appreciation for Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: McQuaig, Scott; Collie, Biff;
